content:
Yes, sure. Here are some examples of the duration of sunrises in cities close to the Arctic Circle during the summer solstice:

- Tromsø, Norway: Located approximately 69 degrees north of the equator, Tromsø experiences the Midnight Sun phenomenon during the summer solstice, where the sun does not set below the horizon, resulting in a continuous period of daylight. The duration of sunrise is therefore calculated as the time when the sun reaches a certain height above the horizon. On the day of the summer solstice, the sun rises at around 12:47 am and sets at around 12:54 am, resulting in a sunrise duration of about 7 minutes.

- Reykjavik, Iceland: Located approximately 64 degrees north of the equator, Reykjavik experiences a sunrise duration of about 3-4 hours on the day of the summer solstice. On this day, the sun rises in Reykjavik at around 2:55 am and sets at around 12:03 am, resulting in approximately 21.5 hours of daylight.

- Murmansk, Russia: Located approximately 69 degrees north of the equator, Murmansk experiences a sunrise duration of about 55 minutes to 1 hour on the day of the summer solstice. On this day, the sun rises at around 2:08 am and sets at around 1:22 am, resulting in approximately 22.5 hours of daylight.

It's worth noting that the duration of sunrises can vary based on several factors such as the actual location within the city, weather conditions, and topography. Additionally, the duration of the sunrise can fluctuate slightly from year to year based on the position of the earth in its orbit around the sun.
